I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the 2007 Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
the Government of the People's Republic of China (PRC) requested that the ADB provide 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Rural  Finance  Development  and  Supervision.  A  Fact-Finding 
Mission  visited  Beijing  and  Shenyang  in  20–27  May  2008.  Following  the  discussions,  an 
understanding  was  reached  on  the  objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates, 
financing  plan,  and  implementation  arrangements  of  the  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.   ISSUES 
 
2.  Poverty  and  inequity  remain  important  development  issues  in  the  PRC  despite  its 
impressive economic growth and remarkable progress in poverty reduction over the past 3 
decades. Most of the country’s poor are concentrated in rural areas. Significant socioeconomic 
disparities have also emerged between the urban and rural sectors, and within the rural sector. 
Policymakers’ concern about these trends is reflected in the PRC’s 11th Five-Year Plan, which 
highlights the need to address rural poverty to achieve equitable development and reduce 
urban–rural disparities. 
 
3.  The Government has recognized that a multipronged approach is essential to address 
rural poverty and equity issues. The importance of improving financial services for the rural 
population, including low-income people, has been identified. This recognition of the role of rural 
financial markets in effecting economic growth, poverty reduction, and the creation of a more 
equitable society is particularly significant for several reasons. First, estimates of both the 
People’s Bank of China (PBC) and the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) suggest 
that only one-third of the more than 750 million people living in rural areas has access to formal 
credit services and that a significant proportion of those without access to credit services have 
an  unmet  demand  for  it.  Second,  increased  access  to  improved  financial services  for  the 
majority of the rural population can contribute significantly in increasing rural economic growth 
and  reducing  poverty.  Third,  such  access  can  also  contribute  to  reducing  socioeconomic 
inequities within rural areas and between the urban and rural sectors. Fourth, the lack of broad 
access to financial services could have significant adverse economic and social consequences 
if the PRC’s high overall levels of economic growth were to slow. Rural nonfarm enterprises, 
which require more access to better quality financial services, would particularly likely suffer and 
their  ability  to  generate  better  incomes  and  more  productive  employment  opportunities  for 
others could be diminished. 
 
4.  There are efforts to develop rural financial markets, introduced under the 11th Five-Year 
Plan. One such initiative is the reform of rural credit cooperatives (RCCs). The RCC system has 
suffered  from  uncertainty  in  the  ownership  structure  and  conflicts  between  policy  and 
commercial orientations. In the past, there was an apparent conflict of interest in having the 
PBC serve as both the supervisor and administrator2 of the rural credit cooperatives system.3 
The lack of a proper regulatory framework for other types of rural finance organizations, such as 
microfinance institutions, had become a major impediment to the emergence of alternatives to 
the rural credit cooperatives system. As a consequence, CBRC expanded the policy and legal

framework to enable new institutional modalities to flourish in rural financial markets, including 
town  and  village  banks,  and  community  credit  cooperatives.  These  new  modalities  have 
expanded the potential of the private sector to invest and participate in formal rural financial 
markets. Despite these initiatives, the Government is aware that accelerating the development 
of competitive rural financial markets requires further systematic public support. The pressure is 
mounting on policymakers to expand such support through a range of fiscal measures. The 
Government is therefore looking into a broader set of measures to develop rural financial 
markets.  
 
5.  Public Policy and Financial Support. The PRC has a long history of substantial public 
support for rural finance. A large amount of this support has been provided to reform and 
restructure the existing rural finance institutional network and to finance rural lending operations. 
However, the current status of rural financial markets tends to suggest that such support has not 
generated significant positive and sustainable results. A major drawback of past measures was 
that these did not remove the need for further public support over the long term and had not 
encouraged improved institutional behavior. Public support often involved writing-off loan losses 
and meeting other expenses, which created moral hazard problems, distorted market behavior, 
and undermined the financial viability of service providers.4  
 
6.  CBRC, in principle, supports the adoption of a more effective and sustainable public 
support  strategy  to  develop  rural  financial  markets  through  both  supply-  and  demand-side 
interventions. There are two major objectives for such public support: (i) restructuring existing 
rural finance institutions to enhance their sustainability, and (ii) improving access to finance in 
areas where financial services have been proven to be commercially unsustainable in the short 
and medium terms. How such public support should be provided to promote competitive rural 
financial markets to maximize economic and social benefits, while minimizing distortions in the 
market, is a key element of the proposed strategy. CBRC recognizes that many effective 
supporting policies have been adopted in both developed and developing countries and it 
requires assistance to better understand how these policies have been conceived, formulated, 
implemented, and evaluated in various contexts; and what lessons can be drawn to arrive at 
more effective policies for the development of rural financial markets in the PRC.  
 
7.  Regulatory  and  Supervisory  System.  The  Government  seeks  to  improve  the 
regulatory  system  to  strengthen  trends  supporting  the  establishment  of  sustainable  rural 
financial markets within the diverse market structure expected to emerge as a result of recent 
reform measures. The creation of CBRC and the transfer of the responsibility for regulation and 
supervision of rural financial institutions, including rural credit cooperatives, from PBC to it was 
one such measure. CBRC has also taken a number of measures to improve its capacity to 
effectively regulate and supervise rural financial institutions. These include introduction of risk-
based  asset  classifications,  and  differentiated  supervisory  management  for  rural  financial 
institutions based on risk and compliance ratings. However, rural finance, and rural credit in 
particular, has its own characteristics, and specific regulatory practices need to be appropriately 
designed and implemented. CBRC is cognizant of this need. Characteristics of rural finance in 
the PRC include: (i) strong seasonality with annual and perennial agriculture production patterns, 
and vulnerability to natural disasters that may warrant a more flexible, risk-based categorization 
of assets; (ii) varied ownership and capital structure of rural financial institutions, such as credit 
cooperatives and lending-only institutions, which have different capital adequacy requirements 
and taxation treatment; (iii) new types of rural financial institutions, such as town and village

3   
banks,  and  community  credit  cooperatives  that  need  more  adaptive  regulatory  norms  and 
supervisory treatment; and (iv) adoption of new approaches and technologies by rural financial 
institutions aimed at lowering operational costs and deepening outreach, such as cellphone 
banking and the use of banking agents, which also require targeted regulatory and supervisory 
treatment.  
 
8.  A primary thrust of ADB assistance under the country partnership strategy (CPS)5 
completed in 2008 is to support inclusive growth and balanced development. ADB’s indicative 
areas for interventions, as stipulated by the financial sector plan under the CPS, comprise of 
building an inclusive, market-oriented, rural finance system; supporting policy and regulatory 
reform; and strengthening financial supervision and coordination among financial regulators in 
rural  finance.  ADB  has  previously  provided  TA  to  the  PRC  to  strengthen  the  regulatory 
framework of the financial system, and to improve access to finance by rural residents. These 
include, among other forms of assistance, two TAs to strengthen CBRC’s supervisory capacity6 
and a TA to support the reform of rural credit cooperatives and the development of microfinance 
institutions.7
 
9.    CBRC needs to ensure that its regulatory practices facilitate sustainable growth 
of  rural  financial  services.  Regulatory  practices  need  to  be  designed  to  support  outreach 
objectives, but not at the expense of the stability and quality of rural financial services. A proper 
balance needs to be maintained between supportive regulatory practices and a healthy and 
stable  rural  financial  system.  Hence,  CBRC  wants  to  review  the  regulatory  policies  and 
practices relating to successful rural financial operations around the world and ensure that their 
application would be consistent with the diverse rural financial markets in the PRC that are 
beginning to emerge and are likely to grow in size and scope in the medium term.  Being chair 
of the Government’s inter-agency rural finance development working group, CBRC requires 
assistance  to  understand,  in  a  systematic  way,  how  these  policies  have  been  conceived, 
formulated, implemented, and evaluated. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA will result in increased access to financial services for a larger proportion of the 
rural  population  that  is  currently  underserved  or  un-served  by  rural  financial  markets.  Its  
outcome will be improved policy formulation, institutional coordination, and regulation in rural 
financial  markets  with  sufficient  outreach  in  both  the  depth  and  breadth  of  rural  financial 
services. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will examine the following issues in rural financial markets development: 
 
(i)  Role  of  public  policy  and  financial  support.  The  TA  will  conduct  a 
socioeconomic  impact  analysis  of  past  measures  of  public  support  for  rural

financial  markets;  examine  how  public  support  measures  such  as  interest 
subsidies,  refinancing,  preferential  taxes,  regulatory  support  for  merger  and 
acquisitions, legal and regulatory policies, and state ownership in rural financial 
institutions have been used to develop rural financial markets development in a 
select  number  of  developed  countries;  review  existing  legal  and  institutional 
arrangements,  decision-making  processes,  and  powers  and  accountability  to 
identify infirmities, perverse incentives, and obstacles in the existing legal and 
institutional arrangements; and prepare recommendations for an effective public 
policy support program for the development of rural financial markets to meet the 
objective of (a) enhancing sustainability of rural financial institutions to increase 
the depth and breadth of their outreach, and (b) improving access to finance in 
areas  where  financial  services  have  been  proven  to  be  commercially 
unsustainable in the short to medium term. Among the public support policies 
that  would  be  considered  are  effective  targeting,  time-boundness,  and 
performance-based allocation and implementation. 
(ii)  Need for adaptive regulatory framework. The TA will examine current legal 
and regulatory policies and practices for rural credit operations at the central and 
local levels; identify salient features of the operations of rural financial institutions 
as compared to other financial institutions; provide recommendations on how to 
strike  a  balance  among  (a)  adequate  financial  services  in  rural  areas,  (b) 
encouraging innovation to facilitate sustainable rural finance outreach, and (c) 
financial  soundness  of  rural  financial  institutions;  and  identify  the  capacity-
building  support  needs  of  CBRC  (at  the  provincial  level)  and  of  rural  credit 
cooperatives to implement improved legal and regulatory policies and practices. 
 
12.  The TA will generate the following outputs: 
  
(i)  Output 1. The TA will produce a socioeconomic analysis of past public support 
measures in the PRC and an examination of how public support measures have 
been used in developed countries. This output will provide lessons for designing 
an effective public policy support program and lead to a set of recommendations 
in the form of a series of policy notes for high-level decision makers for an 
effective  public  support  policy  for  rural  financial  markets  development.  The 
recommendations will highlight (a) what type of support should be considered; (b) 
how public support can be designed in an incentive-compatible manner; (c) how 
public  support  programs  may  be  effectively  implemented  to  ensure  their 
expected outcomes; and (d) what public support audit and evaluation program 
need to be put in place to ensure transparency, fiscal integrity, effectiveness, and 
impact. 
(ii)  Output 2. The TA will likewise examine regulatory practices and give a set of 
specific recommendations that would promote the sustainable outreach of rural 
financial services, in general, and expand those services to low-income groups 
and their micro- and small-enterprises, in particular. International experience and 
lessons learned will be used in the formulation of these practices. 
(iii)  Output 3. The third set of outputs from the TA will consist of reports and policy 
notes that will allow high-level decision makers, the staff of CBRC’s head and 
local-level offices, and other concerned agencies to gain a deeper understanding 
of how public policies can be formulated and implemented in a market-friendly 
manner  without  undermining  the  sustainable  development  of  rural  financial 
markets.  In  addition,  better-designed  curriculums  for  capacity  building  and

5   
knowledge  transfer  will  allow  local-level  CBRC  staff  to  identify  sustainable, 
outreach-oriented, regulatory practices. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000 equivalent. The Government has requested ADB 
to finance $400,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding 
program. The Government will finance the balance of the cost, equivalent to $150,000, through 
the  provision  of  office  accommodation,  counterpart  staff,  transportation,  and  other  related 
services. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  CBRC will be the Executing Agency (EA) and the Cooperative Finance Supervision 
Department of CBRC will be the responsible department. A coordination group will be set up, 
comprised of senior officials of the relevant government and regulatory agencies, to provide 
overall  guidance  for  project  implementation.  The  EA  will  provide  the  consultants  with  the 
necessary office space, counterpart staff, transportation, and other services, and will arrange 
meeting appointments for the consultants with relevant agencies and organizations.  
 
15.  The TA will engage two international consultants and two national consultants for a total 
of 10 person-months. The two international consultants will be the team leader and international 
rural finance development specialist (2.5 person-months), and an international rural finance 
regulation  and  supervision  specialist  (1.5  person-months).  They  will  be  supported  by 
corresponding  national  consultants.  There  will  be  a  separate  budget  to  engage  additional 
international  and  domestic  Resource  Persons  for  specific  technical  areas  during  TA 
implementation,  as  the  need  arises.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3. The international and national consultants will be selected and engaged on an 
individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  Equipment  will  be  procured  by  the  EA  in  accordance  with 
procedures acceptable to ADB. Disbursements under the TA will be conducted in line with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, as amended from time to time). 
For equipment, training seminars, and conferences, an advance payment facility could be used. 
 
16.  The  TA  is  expected  to  begin  in  January  2009  and  end  in  December  2009.  The 
consultants will submit the following to both ADB and the EA: (i) inception reports 2 weeks after 
the commencement of their services, (ii) interim progress reports at appropriate stages during 
TA implementation, (iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of the contract, and (iv) final 
reports 2 weeks after receiving comments from the EA and ADB. All reports must be submitted 
in English, and the draft final report and the final report should also be submitted in Chinese. 
Workshops will be organized periodically to disseminate the consultants’ findings and to discuss 
policy recommendations. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Rural  Finance  Development  and 
Supervision, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  international  consultants  are  primarily  responsible  for  introducing  international 
experiences  and  best  practices,  providing  advisory  services  on  key  technical  issues,  and 
disseminating lessons learned and providing recommendations to policymakers. The national 
consultants are responsible for all technical aspects of technical assistance (TA) implementation 
and training. 
 
A.  International Consultants (4 person-months) 
 
1.  Team Leader and Rural Finance Development Specialist (2.5 person- months) 
 
2.  The consultant will assume the role of the team leader and be responsible for the overall 
management of TA implementation, timely delivery of high-quality interim and final reports, 
identification and management of source persons in various technical tasks, and organization of 
workshops and training activities. The consultant should possess sufficient knowledge and 
experience in the area of public policy and fiscal support for rural financial markets, both in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) and other countries. Knowledge of the Chinese language is 
an advantage. Specifically, the consultant will: 
(i)  identify different major public support measures for rural finance development 
that have been implemented in the PRC at the national and provincial levels 
aimed at (a) enhancing the sustainability of existing rural finance institutions, and 
(b) improving access to finance in areas where financial services have been 
proven to be commercially unsustainable; 
(ii)  based on the existing literature, provide a brief analysis of how public policy 
support has evolved in developed countries; 
(iii)  identify lessons from the experiences in developed countries that could be useful 
for the PRC and that (a) enhance the sustainability of existing rural financial 
institutions and expand the depth and breadth of their outreach, and (b) improve 
access to finance in areas where financial services have been proven to be 
commercially unsustainable; 
(iv)  present and discuss these lessons at a consultation workshop for concerned 
high-level policy makers to improve their understanding of the issues involved; 
(v)  through a consultative process, prepare a set of recommendations in the form of 
a series of policy notes for high-level decision makers for an effective public 
support policy for the development of rural financial markets that will promote 
deepened and sustainable outreach of rural financial services; 
(vi)  provide recommendations on how to implement the policy effectively while taking 
local market conditions into account;  
(vii)  conduct  workshops  for  concerned  China  Banking  Regulatory  Commission 
(CBRC) staff to improve their understanding of the relevant issues; and 
(viii)  prepare  a  public  support  audit  and  evaluation  program  to  assess  the 
effectiveness and impact of the public support policy measures.

2.  Rural Finance Regulation and Supervision Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will: 
(i)  examine the legal and regulatory policies and practices used for rural financial 
institutions in the PRC; 
(ii)  evaluate  their  impact  on  outreach,  sustainability,  and  potential  market 
competition; 
(iii)  identify sustainable, outreach-oriented legal and regulatory policies and practices, 
and how these could be used for rural credit operations at the local level; 
(iv)  briefly  outline  international  best  practices  on  the  regulation  of  rural  credit 
operations, with special emphasis on practices that promote agricultural lending 
and lending to low-income households in a cost-effective manner;  
(v)  recommend ways to strike a balance among (a) adequate financial services in 
rural  areas,  (b)  encouraging  innovation  to  facilitate  sustainable  rural  finance 
outreach, and (c) financial soundness of rural financial institutions; and identify 
the capacity-building support needs at CBRC (at the provincial level) and rural 
credit cooperatives to implement improved regulatory practices; and 
(vi)  in  consultation  with  local-level  regulators,  recommend  a  set  of  legal  and 
regulatory policies and practices that support sustainable rural finance operations. 
 
B.  National Consultants (6 person-months) 
 
4.  National  consultants  with  in-depth  country  and  sector  knowledge,  and  a  solid 
background in performance audit theory and practices will be recruited. These consultants will 
help  the  international  consultants  to  quickly  become  familiar  with  the  required  tasks  by 
researching and compiling a set of policies, regulations, and procedures adopted by, or relevant 
to, CBRC; and ensuring that the outputs of the international consultants are appropriate in the 
context of conditions at the PRC.  They are also expected to assume key responsibilities in 
conducting training sessions, particularly for CBRC’s local-level staff.  Knowledge of the English 
language is required. 
 
1.  Rural Finance Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
5.  The consultant will: 
(i)  work  together  with  the  international  rural  finance  development  specialist  to 
identify major public support measures for rural finance development that have 
been implemented in the PRC at the national and provincial levels; 
(ii)  identify lessons that could be useful for the PRC from its own public support 
measures  and  from  measures  that  have  been  implemented  in  developed 
countries; 
(iii)  assist in the conduct of workshops for concerned CBRC staff to improve their 
understanding of the issues involved; 
(iv)  assist in the drafting of a broad policy on public support for the development of 
rural financial markets that would promote sustainable outreach of rural financial 
services and deepen their outreach; 
(v)  assist in the effective implementation of the policy while taking local market 
conditions into account; and 
(vi)  prepare guidelines for the public support audit and evaluation program to assess 
the effectiveness and impact of the public support policy measures.

(i)  work  together  with  the  international  rural  finance  regulation  and  supervision 
specialist  in  a  detailed  examination  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  policies  and 
practices used for rural financial institutions in the PRC and an evaluation of their 
impact on outreach, sustainability, and potential market competition; 
(ii)  compare  international  best  practices  relating  to  regulation  of  rural  credit 
operations,  with  a  special  emphasis  on  practices  that  promote  agricultural 
lending and lending to low-income households in a cost-effective manner;  
(iii)  identify all relevant issues for striking a balance among (a) adequate financial 
services in rural areas, (b) encouraging innovation to facilitate sustainable rural 
finance outreach, and (c) financial soundness of rural financial institutions;  
(iv)  recommend  a  set  of  legal  and  regulatory  policies  and  practices  suitable  for 
sustainable rural credit operations;  
(v)  assist  in  conducting  workshops  for  concerned  CBRC  staff  to  improve  their 
understanding of the issues involved; and 
(vi)  conduct capacity-building sessions for CBRC staff (at the provincial level) and 
rural credit cooperatives to implement improved regulatory practices.
